Patch Set 7: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Chris Burroughs

Ah. There is something to discuss here: I designed (wrote the changelog and the top-comment in lib/index.js) `mod_triton.createClient` to be *async*, in that handles calling .init(). However, I forgot to change the implementation to that. :)

So, two options:

1. keep mod_triton.createClient as is (users need to code to do the 3 steps: create, init, unlock key).

2. Change to the async form.


The case for #1: It is basically the same API as the raw 'tritonapi.createClient'.

The case for #2: It could mean less boilerplate for using code. With the sync style, in *general* you need to (a) have a try/cache around the mod_triton.createClient, then (b) handle the error for tritonapi.init, then (b) handle the error for unlock key.  For style #2 I could see also adding a option to do the key unlocking as well for a CLI
program, so you could get something like the difference in these two: https://gist.github.com/trentm/38774f57a9ba11dda56a807df075dfb4

Thoughts? If you think style #2 sounds better, I coudl take a stab at it in your branch.

I'm not sure if one approach is obviously more idiomatic in node-land.

#2 looks terser in your example, but I'm not sure in practice if it saves that much code since the createClient is in CLI.init already.  Right now we:
 (1) Always create (except on `--version`)
 (2) Usually init, except for profile manipulation
 (2a) Sometimes (just docker-setup?) create different tritonapi by name
 (3) If we init, we usually unlock, but not for bash-completion.

But at the point we are currently calling createClient I'm worried we don't know which of those it will be.
I don't mean for the `triton` CLI's usage of mod_triton. I mean for other software using node-triton as a module. For them I think having an easier boilerplate could be quite helpful.
So an alternative way just for the module common case along the lines of createAndInitButDoNotUnlockAsync?

Yup basically. Also with an option to also "do the unlock using the convenience function that uses the CLI to prompt for a passphrase" for those implementing a CLI.

Trying to make that first hurdle for modules users easier.
in alphabetical order in this block please
That wording would make me worry that my private key will get blown away. Can we re-word that?
Gave it another word smithing pass.

1. Can we avoid this prompting if the key isn't encrypted? 

2. Can we rejigger the order so that, if we need to ask this of the user, we do so before 'cliSetupTritonApi' (currently above) will already have prompted for the key's passphrase. Else the user will enter their passphrase and *then* possibly want to just abort anyway.

3. Does this setup do the right thing if there is a private key in a *forwarded* ssh-agent? I.e. in the agent, but the private key isn't accessible.

1. We could, but even if your key isn't encrypted, would a reasonable person want to know if there are copies of private keys being made?  I personally was surprised by this behavior.

2.  We could.  As a consequence a bunch of the checks (is cloudapi up? does this auth work? is docker setup?) would happen later.  I think that's probably more consistent anyway.

3.  My expectation is that the current and with-patch behavior is that if an ssh-agent is used at all, we die.  We talked about that being a worthy followup ticket.
3. Correct -- just below this block, in checkSshPrivKey() we will die because we can't get the private key out of the agent.
Half of these typos are yours ;-)
This would be cleaner as a vasync.pipeline. But meh for now. :)
drop this option, no longer used
Might be better to use the prefix mod_ here -- we use it already elsewhere in sdc-docker and it's the standard for a bunch of other joyent repos.
